Stem: A scientist studied layers of rock on the side of a cliff. In the top layer she found fossilized sand dunes. In the middle layer she found fossils of coral, clamshells, and shark teeth. In the bottom layer she found fossils of fern leaves. What is the correct order of the environments from oldest to youngest?
Choices: A) desert ocean forest, B) desert forest ocean, C) ocean forest desert, D) forest ocean desert
Scenario Justification: Real scenario with multiple fossil layers. Students must reason about superposition and connect fossils to environments. Genuine uncertainty in ordering.
SEP Justification: Students analyze fossil evidence to construct an explanation of environmental change over time. Engages analyzing/interpreting data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that rock layers reveal environmental history and that fossils indicate past environments. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly uses Patterns (fossils in layers = pattern of change over time) but students don't explicitly reason with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Add a follow-up asking students to explain what evidence supports the ordering, requiring explicit use of Patterns in reasoning.

Stem: The pahoehoe lava flows down the side of the Kilauea volcano. Scientists want to predict which way the lava will flow next. The figure shows two paths. Which statement best describes how the lava will flow?
Image/Diagram Description: Map showing Kilauea volcano with two paths W and X
Choices: A) Path W because it is long, B) Path X because it is steep and lets lava move quickly, C) Path W because it is flat, D) Path X because it is short
Scenario Justification: Extended scenario about Hawaiian volcanoes with scientific context. Students must reason about lava flow using topographic reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation predicting lava flow based on slope/topography evidence. Engages constructing explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding Earth surface processes and how gravity and slope affect flow. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect directly — steep slope causes faster lava movement. Students reason causally.
Key Recommendation: Solid question with real phenomenon. Could elevate by asking students to explain WHY steeper paths move lava faster, making the cause-effect reasoning explicit.

Stem: Devils Tower is a landform in Wyoming that was buried underground for millions of years. About 5 million years ago several processes occurred. Which statement best explains one of the layers of rock around the landform?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing Devils Tower with labeled layers X Y Z
Choices: A) Layer Y was once lava, B) Layer Z was once above Layer X, C) Layer Y is younger than Layer X, D) Layer X was once under the ocean
Scenario Justification: Real geological landform with layered rock context. Students must reason about how ocean fossils end up on land. Genuine scientific reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze rock layer evidence to construct an explanation of Earth's history. Engages constructing explanations from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding rock layer formation and past environments. Goes beyond recall to reasoning about geological history.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Stability and Change but not explicitly required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Good geological context. Strengthen by adding fossil evidence in each layer and asking students to reconstruct the environmental history.

Stem: Melissa and Rebecca created models of two waves. Which statement best describes the relationship between the two waves in the models?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing two waves with different amplitudes and wavelengths
Choices: A) Same amplitude, B) Long-wavelength wave has higher amplitude, C) Long-wavelength wave has lower amplitude, D) One is water one is air
Scenario Justification: Students observe wave models and must describe differences in properties. Visual analysis required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret data from wave models. Engages analyzing/interpreting data from models.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding wave properties (amplitude, wavelength) and their relationships. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Patterns is implicitly relevant (wave patterns) but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Add a part B asking students to predict what happens to amplitude if wavelength changes, engaging Cause and Effect.

Stem: The figure shows several layers of rock and a line where there was movement. Part A: Which set of statements best explains the order of events that formed the rock layers?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing rock layers Q E T with a fault line
Choices: A) Q E T, B) T E Q, C) E Q T, D) T Q E
Scenario Justification: Multi-part question about rock layer ordering with a fault line. Students must apply superposition principle. Genuine reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze rock layer evidence and construct an explanation for ordering. Two-part structure adds depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding superposition — bottom layers are oldest. Applied in a specific context with added complexity of fault.
CCC Justification: Implicitly uses Patterns (layer ordering = pattern) but CCC not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good two-part structure. Part B strengthens the question by requiring evidence-based reasoning.

Stem: Part B: Which evidence best supports the answer to Part A?
Choices: A) Layer Q is at top so oldest, B) Layer T is at bottom so oldest, C) Layer Q is thicker so formed first, D) Layers E and T are thicker on one side so formed after Q
Scenario Justification: Part B requires identifying evidence that supports the reasoning in Part A. Good evidence-to-claim structure.
SEP Justification: Explicitly asks students to support their claim with evidence. Directly engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence. Higher practice demand.
DCI Justification: Same DCI as Part A but now applied to evidence evaluation. Students must distinguish relevant from irrelevant evidence.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — bottom position (cause) means older formation (effect). Students must reason causally.
Key Recommendation: Strong question. The evidence-to-claim structure is well designed. Consider adding a third part asking students to explain what the fault line tells us.

Stem: Scientists found layers of rock containing the fossils shown. Which conclusion can scientists make from studying these rock layers?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing 5 fossil layers numbered 1-5 from bottom to top
Choices: A) Fossil 1 is the oldest, B) Fossil 2 is older than Fossil 3, C) Fossil 4 is younger than Fossil 5, D) Fossil 5 is the youngest
Scenario Justification: Another rock layer/fossil question. Students must apply superposition to determine relative fossil ages.
SEP Justification: Students identify a conclusion from rock layer evidence but the reasoning is straightforward application of superposition.
DCI Justification: Requires applying superposition principle to fossil ordering. Slightly repetitive with Q1 Q3 Q5.
CCC Justification: Implicitly uses Patterns but not explicitly.
Key Recommendation: Fourth question on rock layers/superposition (Q1 Q3 Q5a/b Q6). Reduce repetition and replace with questions on other G4 standards.

Stem: Many objects produce heat energy. Students want to sort objects into two groups. Which question should students ask to decide which object to put into Group 2? Group 1: Objects that use electricity to produce heat. Group 2: Objects that use stored energy to produce heat.
Choices: A) How much heat energy? B) How do people use the heat energy? C) Can the object produce heat without being plugged in? D) Can the heat energy be changed?
Scenario Justification: Real sorting task about energy sources. Students must reason about what distinguishes electrical vs stored energy sources.
SEP Justification: Engages Planning and Carrying Out Investigations — students must identify the right question to ask for sorting. Meta-cognitive engagement with scientific practice.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding different energy sources (electrical vs. stored/chemical) and how to distinguish them. Application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (grouping by energy source type) but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good question structure that asks students to formulate a sorting question. Could add images of actual objects to make it more concrete.

Stem: A prairie dog whistles loudly when it senses danger. When it whistles all the prairie dogs nearby run and hide. Which sense helps the other prairie dogs receive this warning?
Choices: A) hearing, B) sight, C) smell, D) taste
Scenario Justification: No real scenario — direct recall of which sense detects sound. Answer is trivially obvious.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Pure recall of the function of hearing.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that hearing processes sound information. Trivially applied.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Too simple. Redesign to present multiple sensory scenarios and ask students to explain how different senses work together to help prairie dogs survive.

Stem: Which form of energy is produced when a person claps his hands?
Choices: A) chemical, B) electrical, C) light, D) sound
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of energy forms. No reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge that clapping produces sound energy. Recall only.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign around a scenario: provide data about different actions and their energy outputs, asking students to match and explain energy transformations.

Stem: Use the drop-down menus to complete: The fossils in the diagram give evidence that the area under the school playground was likely first a ___ and later a ___.
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing rock layers with fossils under a playground
Choices: a) sea/forest/desert, b) sea/forest/desert
Scenario Justification: Applies fossil evidence to determine environmental change over time. Students must sequence two environments from evidence.
SEP Justification: Students analyze fossil evidence to construct a sequence of environmental change. Engages constructing explanations from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of fossils as evidence of past environments and environmental change over time.
CCC Justification: Implicitly uses Patterns (sequence of change) but CCC not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Fifth ESS1-1 question. Strong repetition of this standard. Drop-down format limits response depth.

Stem: A bat uses sound waves to find and catch flying insects. Drag the statements into the correct order to describe the process.
Choices: Sound waves produced by bat / Sound waves hit an object / Sound waves bounce off toward bat's ears
Correct Answer: 1. Produced by bat; 2. Hit object; 3. Bounce back to ears
Scenario Justification: Real phenomenon (echolocation) with sequencing task. Students must understand wave behavior to order the process.
SEP Justification: Students construct a model of echolocation by sequencing steps. Engages Developing and Using Models.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sound waves travel and reflect off objects. Applied understanding of wave behavior.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — each step causes the next in the sequence. Causal chain reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: Good application of wave concepts to a real phenomenon. Strengthen by asking students to explain what would happen if the insect were farther away.

Stem: The bat uses sound waves to find prey. Use drop-down menus to complete: The messages processed by the bat's ___ and the bat's sense of ___ help catch prey.
Choices: a) eyes/taste buds/brain, b) smell/hearing/sight
Scenario Justification: Continues the bat scenario but the actual question is recall about brain processing and hearing sense.
SEP Justification: Students select from options to describe sensory processing. Limited practice engagement.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that the brain processes sensory information. Basic recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: The bat scenario is good but the question itself is simple recall of brain + hearing. Redesign to ask students to explain HOW echolocation helps bats survive better than sight alone.

Stem: Julio wanted to know how his heart and lungs worked together when he ran very fast. He observed that he breathed faster and his heart beat faster while running. Which statement best describes how Julio's heart and lungs support survival during physical activity?
Choices: A) Heart and lungs work less when running, B) Heart and lungs work more when running causing faster breathing and heartbeat, C) No change in function, D) Heart beats slower but breathes faster
Scenario Justification: Real observational scenario. Students must connect organ function to survival needs during exercise.
SEP Justification: Students select an explanation for observed phenomena but reasoning is straightforward. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how organ systems (circulatory and respiratory) work together. Applied understanding.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Systems and System Models (organs as parts of a system) but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario but answer is essentially restating the observation. Ask students to explain WHY the heart and lungs work harder — what do muscles need more of?

Stem: Roger poured water over a pile of sand. Some of the sand washed away. This process is similar to which of the following?
Choices: A) eruption of a volcano, B) erosion of canyon walls, C) uplifting of mountain ranges, D) forming of desert dunes
Scenario Justification: Simple analogy question comparing sand washing to erosion. Minimal reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students make a connection between a simple observation and a real-world process. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of erosion as the movement of earth materials by water. Basic application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (water causes erosion) but trivially.
Key Recommendation: Too straightforward. Redesign to provide data about erosion rates under different conditions and ask students to predict and explain.

Stem: Which statement explains why light from the Sun can warm up water in a glass?
Choices: A) Water reflects light and converts to sound, B) Water absorbs light and converts to motion, C) Water reflects light and converts to electrical, D) Water absorbs light and converts to heat
Scenario Justification: Simple question about energy conversion. Minimal scenario.
SEP Justification: Students select a correct energy transformation. Limited practice engagement.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that light energy can be converted to heat energy. Recall-level with some application.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall of energy conversion. Redesign by providing experimental data showing temperature changes in water under different light conditions.

Stem: Rafael conducts an investigation to find out if grass growing on a hillside will help stop soil erosion. He collects two soil samples — one with grass and one without. After pouring water the water under the grass looks clearer. What conclusion can Rafael make?
Choices: A) Grass helped hold soil in place, B) Grass helped move water through soil, C) Soil without grass was sticky, D) Soil without grass was loose
Scenario Justification: Investigation scenario with experimental setup and observations. Students must draw a conclusion from evidence.
SEP Justification: Students analyze experimental results and draw a conclusion. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from an investigation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding erosion and how plant roots stabilize soil. Applied in an investigation context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — grass roots (cause) prevent erosion (effect). Students must reason causally from evidence.
Key Recommendation: Good investigation-based question. Strengthen by adding a Part B asking what would happen if Rafael increased the water flow rate.

Stem: Which two numbers in the picture of a flower show the male and female parts?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of flower with numbered parts (1-4)
Choices: A) 1 and 2, B) 2 and 3, C) 2 and 4, D) 3 and 4
Scenario Justification: Image-based identification question. Students must identify flower reproductive structures from a diagram.
SEP Justification: No science practice beyond identification/recall from a labeled diagram.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of flower anatomy. Recall of structural identification.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure anatomy recall. Redesign to ask students to explain the FUNCTION of male and female flower parts in reproduction, engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: In your body what two organs work together to make sure oxygen gets to all other organs?
Choices: A) Lungs and kidneys, B) Heart and lungs, C) Brain and kidneys, D) Heart and liver
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Pure recall of organ function. No reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that heart and lungs work together for oxygen delivery. Recall only.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Combine with Q13 scenario about exercise and ask students to trace the path of oxygen from lungs through blood to muscles.

Stem: Students visit a riverbank and notice soil wearing away exposed roots and visible rocks. Which claim is BEST supported by their observations?
Choices: A) Animals are digging holes, B) Rocks push through soil on their own, C) Rainwater is slowly eroding soil, D) Roots are pulling soil away
Scenario Justification: Real observational scenario at a riverbank. Students must evaluate claims against evidence. Good claim-evidence structure.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing claims based on observational evidence. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding erosion processes and distinguishing valid from invalid explanations. Applied reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — students reason about what causes soil loss. Must evaluate causal claims.
Key Recommendation: Strong question with claim-evidence structure. Could elevate by asking students to explain why answer C is better than D using specific evidence.

Stem: A student strikes a tuning fork and brings it close to a hanging cork. The cork begins to swing. Which statement BEST explains what this shows about sound transferring energy?
Choices: A) Sound waves from vibrating fork carried energy through air and caused cork to move, B) Air heated up from sound, C) Fork created electrical energy, D) Sound made air disappear
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario. Students must explain energy transfer from sound waves to object motion.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for an observed phenomenon. Engages Constructing Explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sound carries energy and can cause motion. Applied in an observation context.
CCC Justification: Engages Energy and Matter — energy transfer from sound to motion. Students reason about energy flow.
Key Recommendation: Good question connecting sound energy to motion. Strengthen by asking what would happen if the fork were held farther away.

Stem: A cross section of three sedimentary rock layers is shown. Which represents the rock layers from youngest to oldest?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing layers X Y Z
Choices: A) X→Y→Z, B) X→Z→Y, C) Y→Z→X, D) Z→Y→X
Scenario Justification: Another rock layer ordering question. Sixth ESS1-1 question. Students apply superposition.
SEP Justification: Straightforward application of superposition. Limited practice depth for this repetition.
DCI Justification: Same DCI applied in the same way as Q1 Q3 Q5 Q6 Q10. Severe redundancy.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged beyond what's been tested multiple times.
Key Recommendation: SIXTH rock layer question. Critical redundancy — this standard is massively over-tested. Replace with questions on other G4 standards.

Stem: Citizens surveyed about energy resources for a new power plant. How many citizens chose natural resources that do not add to air pollution?
Image/Diagram Description: Table showing survey results for different energy types
Choices: Tech Enhanced Item — count from table
Scenario Justification: Data reading task. Students identify non-polluting resources and count from a table.
SEP Justification: Students analyze data in a table but the task is basic data reading, not interpretation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding which resources are non-polluting. Applied at classification level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Basic data reading. Improve by asking students to compare trade-offs between polluting and non-polluting resources.

Stem: Some natural resources provide energy without burning. Most produce more energy at certain times. Which combination produces steady energy from non-burning sources?
Choices: A) Wind and natural gas, B) Water and Sunlight, C) Sunlight and oil, D) Wind and coal
Scenario Justification: Students must identify non-burning resources and reason about steady vs intermittent energy. Some analysis required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze energy source characteristics. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding renewable vs nonrenewable resources and their availability patterns. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (energy availability patterns) but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good concept but could be stronger with data showing energy output patterns over time for students to analyze.

Stem: The toy oven shown uses a lightbulb to bake small cakes. What types of energy does the toy oven use to bake cakes?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of toy oven with lightbulb
Choices: A) Electrical and heat, B) Motion and electrical, C) Heat and motion, D) Light and sound
Scenario Justification: Simple energy identification question with a toy context.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall/identification of energy types.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of energy forms in a device. Recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign to ask students to trace the energy conversions: electrical → light → heat, and explain each step.

Stem: Which object requires only energy of motion to perform its main function?
Choices: A B C D
Scenario Justification: Image-based energy identification. Students must determine which object uses only kinetic energy.
SEP Justification: No practice beyond recall/classification from images.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of energy of motion. Recall/classification level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Image-dependent recall. Without seeing the images the question lacks depth. Add explanatory component.

Stem: The city of Riverside is dealing with flooding at its community center near a river. Given constraints (cannot construct new buildings; changes only to the community center), which action could address the flooding?
Choices: A) Build wall near river, B) Raise community center floor above water level, C) Block doors to stop water, D) Build new center away from river
Scenario Justification: Strong engineering design question with explicit constraints. Students must evaluate solutions against stated constraints. Real-world problem.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate solutions against criteria and constraints. Engages Designing Solutions to Problems.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design process and constraint-based reasoning. Applied at decision-making level.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (flooding cause, solutions effect) and Systems thinking (constraints limit solutions).
Key Recommendation: Excellent constraint-based engineering question. One of the strongest items on this test. Could add a Part B asking students to explain WHY their chosen solution meets both constraints.

Stem: Two solid blocks A and B are heated to different temperatures. The blocks are placed so they touch. Which statement correctly describes heat flow direction?
Choices: A) B to A because B is colder, B) Neither is hotter so no flow, C) A to B because A is hotter, D) No flow because they're touching
Scenario Justification: Basic heat transfer question. Students must apply hot-to-cold heat flow principle.
SEP Justification: Students apply a principle to predict heat flow. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that heat flows from warmer to cooler objects. Direct application.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (temperature difference causes heat flow) in a basic way.
Key Recommendation: Basic recall of heat transfer direction. Redesign with data showing temperature changes over time and ask students to predict final temperatures.

Stem: A cup of tea is at 85°F. Then thermal energy decreases. Assuming mass remains the same, what could be a possible new temperature?
Scenario Justification: Simple application of the relationship between thermal energy and temperature.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct application of a definition.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that decreased thermal energy means decreased temperature. Basic.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Trivially simple. Redesign by providing a graph of temperature over time and asking students to explain the energy transfers happening.

Stem: Sarah rubs a plastic ruler with cloth and it becomes charged. Small paper pieces stick to it. Complete the model: The ruler is ___ and the cloth is ___.
Image/Diagram Description: Drag and drop with 'negatively charged' and 'positively charged'
Choices: negatively charged / positively charged
Correct Answer: Ruler: negatively charged; Cloth: positively charged
Scenario Justification: Real investigation scenario about static electricity. Students must apply knowledge of charge transfer to complete a model.
SEP Justification: Students complete a model of charge transfer. Engages Developing and Using Models.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of static electricity and charge transfer between materials. Application-level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (rubbing causes charge transfer) but not deeply.
Key Recommendation: Good model-completion question. Strengthen by asking students to predict what happens when the charged ruler is brought near the cloth again.

Stem: Jalen places a book on a table in a room with no windows and no lights. He cannot see it. When he turns on a lamp he sees the book clearly. Which explanation BEST describes why?
Choices: A) Eyes adjusted and created light, B) Light from lamp bounced off book and entered eyes, C) Book glowed when lamp turned on, D) Lamp pulled book into view using heat
Scenario Justification: Real scenario about light and vision. Students must apply understanding of light reflection for vision.
SEP Justification: Students select an explanation but the correct answer is well-known. Limited practice depth.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that we see objects because light reflects off them into our eyes. Core optics concept.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (light reflection causes vision) in a basic way.
Key Recommendation: Good scenario but answer is fairly obvious. Strengthen by asking what would happen with a mirror in the room or asking students to draw a diagram of the light path.
